awd_titl_txt: Workshops on Augmenting Individual Intelligence by Collaborating with People and Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
Most impactful innovations involve people interacting with each other and with the tools that they build explicitly to help them think and/or perform better.  The investigators will organize two workshops to explore the ways in which an individual’s thinking is augmented and shaped by other people as well as by tools.  Coordination among people, artificial intelligence systems, decision algorithms, and learning technologies can give rise to adaptive problem solving far beyond the capabilities of single individuals.  Workshop topics will include how to: facilitate the spread of useful information while reducing misinformation, combine judgments from many individuals (humans and other animals) for improved decision making, create policies and infrastructures that allow groups to effectively solve their shared problems, best combine the strengths of human and computer problem solving to create systems more advanced than either component on their own, and use computers to make human learning more efficient and flexible.   The workshops will feature panelist presentations organized into themes and monthly group discussions.  A broader impact of the workshop is to provide a venue for students anywhere in the world to learn about exciting developments in augmented intelligence.  For students coming from smaller universities with few resources for research, the workshop would provide exposure to state-of-the-art research and opportunities to interact with leading researchers in this emerging field.  The topic of augmented intelligence represents an exciting area of research that can inform many applications including: the optimization of team coordination, the design of intelligent tutoring systems,  computer support for human decision making, and the organization of social media platforms.

This two-part, temporally and geographically distributed workshop will integrate perspectives from cognitive scientists, computer scientists, education researchers, neuroscientists, and biologists to lay the foundations of a shared conceptual framework for a new science of augmented intelligence, premised on the observation that people very rarely solve problems or develop understandings on their own.  Instead, people recruit other people and technologies to help them, and to such a large extent that the apt unit for understanding cognition is typically not an individual person, but rather a larger system that incorporates multiple people and the tools that they created to enhance their capabilities. The workshop participants will grapple with theoretical and applied questions involving the nature of minds, how adaptive systems come into existence that can robustly solve a wide range of problems, and how humans and machines can complement each other’s strengths during learning and knowledge creation. The workshop seeks to stimulate new research directions at the confluence of theoretical, empirical, and technological advances that hold promise of developing an integrative science of augmented intelligence, drawling from multiple disciplinary perspectives.  Deliverable products from the workshop will include online public videos of participants’ lectures, archives of conversations, and special issues of journals devoted to augmented intelligence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this workshop has been to contribute to laying the foundation for a genuine science of augmented intelligence by bringing together researchers interested in how people create cognitive systems at a scale larger than the individual human.  These systems can involve coordination among people, between people and the tools they create, or a combination of those.  Our focus, thus, has been on how people augment their intelligence by creating partnerships with other people and technologies.

 

We created a distributed workshop in which participants gathered together live on Zoom almost every Thursday for 7 months, from June 16th, 2022 to December 15, 2022.  We recruited 42 prominent researchers from psychology, computer science, informatics, network science, animal collective behavior, economics, and education to give presentations.  On each session, two researchers each gave 30 minute presentations followed by individual Q&A sessions and then by a broader 20 minute discussion of common issues.  In addition to these speaker-focused sessions, we had three open-ended discussions of general workshop themes in which all registered participants were invited to contribute.  The workshop was very well attended.  We had 587 registered workshop participants.  See https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1OrAwzCoTUQCpFDPxxUyDPSqyefxXOfFFv2zp7LXyUvM/edit?usp=sharing for information about all registered participants.  The workshop presentations and discussions were recorded and archived on Youtube at https://www.youtube.com/@augmentedintelligenceworks9253/videos so that they would be publicly available.  Approximately 30-40 “live” participants attended each of the workshops via Zoom, and many more people watched the resulting recordings on Youtube.  The average number of views per recording after 9 months is about 150, and the total number of viewings for all 23 videos is currently over 4,000.

In addition to the workshop, we recruited selected workshop speakers to prepare rapporteur reports that integrated speakers’ presentations into underlying themes.  The themes that were identified are:

 

1)     Combining human and machine strengths

How can the efforts of people and machines best be combined to produce creative and effective solutions that neither would be able to generate on their own?

Under what conditions can such complementarity arise, and what types of trade-offs between different desiderata (e.g., accuracy, sensitivity, different senses of fairness, …) might it lead to?

How important is it for people and machines to understand each other to create effective teams?

What will it take for people to be able to trust the solutions from AI systems?

What are the implications of viewing human-AI systems as a team for current practices of design and evaluation in AI/ML in general and trustworthy AI/ML in particular?

 

2)     Collective algorithms

How do decentralized and distributed algorithms for solving problems differ from traditional approaches?

What are the strengths and weaknesses of swarm algorithms?

Do biological systems suggest algorithms that can be applied to problems from superficially dissimilar domains?

 

3)     Improving the performance of human groups

What infrastructural supports exist to allow agents to better coordinate with each other?

What are the important kinds of infrastructural support: formal and informal discussion, laws and rule systems, technological aids for facilitating the sharing of ideas, online forums, competitions, and peer vs teacher instruction.

What are the prospects for communities developing their own infrastructures for supporting coordination?

 

4)     Social coordination

How can agents in a social network best coordinate to solve problems?

What is known about the strategies that artificial and natural agents use to coordinate, and what are the successes and pitfalls of these strategies?

How does the performance of different strategies interact with the nature of the problem being solved, the number of agents, and the benefits of exploration vs exploitation?

 

5)     Computer-assisted learning/education

How can new technologies best be used to augment human intelligence?

Should we be aiming to have computer systems provide scaffolds for constructing stand-alone human knowledge or systems that are designed to work interactively with people?

 

 

6)     Effective AI for humans

How must AI that is designed to be used with humans be different from stand-alone AI?

For AI systems that are going to be good partners for people, what is the role of explicability, justification, computational models of human thinking, incorporating human perceptual and cognitive constraints, values, and emotions?

 

7)     Spread of (mis)information

At a social scale, how does information and misinformation spread in a group?

How do network homophily, filter bubbles, and motivated belief formation modify information spread?

 

We have resulting reports, one of which has been published and four of which are currently under review:

 

1.      Dubova, M., Galesic, M., & Goldstone, R. L. (2022). Cognitive Science of Augmented Intelligence. Cognitive Science, 46(12), e13229.

2.      Wu, C., Dale, R., & Hawkins, R. Group coordination catalyzes individual and cultural intelligence (provisional draft). 

3.      Seth Frey's piece on social mechanics (provisional draft).

4.      Dale, R. & Rosen, Z. Augmented Bibliometric Community Analysis (provisional draft).

5.      Rajaram, S. False Augmented Intelligence: Cognitive Science of Misinformation Spread. 

These rapporteur reports are available for public access at: https://sites.google.com/view/augintworkshop/resources
